title: 113_s2286
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cutting Contractor Use and Taxpayer Savings Act of 2014". It includes findings related to the Act. Since 2002, the Department of Defense has spent over $2 trillion on service contractors, creating a shadow government largely dependent on taxpayers. Studies show contractors can cost taxpayers double what Armed Forces members would. In 2013, the Department spent $180 billion on service contractors, making it the largest buyer of services in the Federal Government. Around 30% of the intelligence community workforce consists of service contractors focused on profit. Since 2002, Congress has enacted legislation to improve the Department of Defense's management of service contractors. In 2013, the Government Accountability Office found that there are no metrics in place to determine the effects of these actions. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will provide a comprehensive analysis of service contractors' inventory, including types of contracts expanded after 2002 and identifying redundancies. The analysis will be publicly available. SEC. 4. Defense Contract Audit Agency to audit service contracts separately from manufacturing contracts and report findings to congressional defense committees within 180 days of enactment. Reports will be made public. SEC. 5. Service Acquisition Improvement Plan. SEC. 5. Service Acquisition Improvement Plan required within 180 days of enactment. Under Secretary of Defense to submit plan to congressional defense committees with baseline data, specific goals, and metrics for improving service acquisition. SEC. 6. The Director of National Intelligence must annually report on the use of service contractors by the intelligence community, including the total amount expended on service contracts. The report may be submitted in classified form. The amendment limits the costs of compensation for contractor and subcontractor employees, with exceptions for specialists, in civilian and defense contracts. Amendment to title 10, United States Code, limits compensation costs for contractor and subcontractor employees, with exceptions for specialists. Repeal of section 1127 of title 41, United States Code. The beginning of chapter 11 of title 10, United States Code, is amended by removing the item related to section 1127. This amendment applies only to costs incurred under contracts entered into 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is required to submit a report on contractor compensation to specific committees annually. The report required by specific committees shall include the total number of contractor employees in narrowly targeted exception positions and taxpayer-funded compensation amounts. The report must include the taxpayer-funded compensation amounts received by contractor employees in narrowly targeted exception positions and the duties and services performed by these employees during the fiscal year. SEC. 8. REDUCTION IN SERVICE CONTRACT SPENDING. SEC. 8. REDUCTION IN SERVICE CONTRACT SPENDING. The Department of Defense is limited in the amount it can spend on service contracts, with a cap set at 67 percent of the amount expended in fiscal year 2014 or 67 percent of the current year's appropriations for service contracts. The Secretary of Defense can waive this limitation with written certification to Congress. The Department of Defense is restricted in the amount it can spend on service contracts, with a cap set at a specified amount. The total expenditure on service contracts in fiscal years after September 30, 2024, should not exceed the amount spent in fiscal year 2002 adjusted for inflation. SEC. 9. CONGRESSIONAL DEFENSE COMMITTEES DEFINED. The term "congressional defense committees" is defined in this Act as stated in section 101(a)(16) of title 10, United States Code.
